channel.title: Hacker News - English
channel.description: Hacker News articles summarized and translated to English

item.title: Microsoft makes Zork open-source
item.description:
They split it into three games titled Zork I, Zork II, and Zork III, all powered by the same underlying system. Each repository includes: Source code for Zork I, Zork II, and Zork III. Running Zork I-III today More than forty years later, Zork is still alive and easier than ever to play.

HN Discussion

Read Original Article

Top 6 Comments:

mike1o1:

https://github.com/historicalsource/zork1 Direct link to the repository

jasonjmcghee:

Pretty huge milestone, congrats. I can imagine how much time / effort it took to get there!

davidw:

Getting a lot of GitHub errors trying to look at the source code.

Still, pretty cool; I remember playing work as a kid.

w4rh4wk5:

Can we get a GPL (or even MIT) release of id Tech 7? Pretty please.

PaulHoule:

… right, Activisiom bought Infocom in the 1980 s…

dang:

(URL changed from https://www.theverge.com/news/824881/zork-open-source-micros..., which points to this)

item.title: Go Cryptography State of the Union
item.description:
I'm very happy about that. It's cryptography that we can do now that resists future quantum computers. Post-quantum cryptography is fast, actually.

HN Discussion

Read Original Article

Top 3 Comments:

alphazard:

I don't know why the standard library crypto packages insist on passing around `[]byte` for things like a seed value, or why we can't just pass in a seed value to a single unambiguous constructor when generating asymmetric keys. Or how the constructor for a key pair could possibly return an error, when the algorithm is supposed to be deterministic.

It all just seems a bit sloppy. Asking for a seed value like `[32]byte` could at least communicate to me that the level of security is at most 256 bits. And removing all dependencies on rand would make it obvious where the entropy must be coming from (the seed parameter). Cloudflare's CIRCL[0] library does a bit better, but shares some of the same problems.

[0] https://github.com/cloudflare/circl

OhMeadhbh:

I'm more of a C person than a Go person, but I am unbelievably happy that someone in that community is using the word "cryptography" to mean cryptography and not Bitcoin.

edoceo:

I'm curious about how GC languages handle crypto. Is it a risk that decrypted stuff or keys and things may be left in memory (heap?) before the next GC cycle?

item.title: Android and iPhone users can now share files, starting with the Pixel 10
item.description:
But we’ve heard from many people that they want a simpler way to share files between devices. Today, we’re introducing a way for Quick Share to work with AirDrop. We built this with security at its core, protecting your data with strong safeguards that were tested by independent security experts.

HN Discussion

Read Original Article

Top 23 Comments:

dlcarrier:

Why is this part of the OS?

emaro:

Fucking finally. I just really hope is also lands in AOSP and will be available on all Android phones in the future.

adenta:

Now we just need universal clipboard between Android and OSX

marcodiego:

If you're using android, you can easily share files over local network (or using your phone as hotspot) with this app: https://f-droid.org/en/packages/com.MarcosDiez.shareviahttp/

If you're not close, telegram fork allow easy sharing of files too.

lazyeye:

The Localsend app is the way

https://localsend.org/

theoldgreybeard:

Nice.

I can also recommend LocalSend.

marcodiego:

Around 2008 I saw two girls, not too versed in technology, share a mp3 song over bluetooth. At the time I thought that if technology finally arrived at the point where "normal people" could be able to do things that required lots of technical knowledge just a few years ago then we were very close to a future where technology could be a giant enabler of powers to everyone.

I am really ashamed by how wrong I was and how WE allowed things to became so artificially limited.

bochoh:

It seems that this is directional, flowing from Android to Apple but not necessarily back (e.g., me airdropping a photo to my parent who uses Android). I'd love for this to work in the other direction as well.

alistairSH:

Is the benefit transferring "local" via BT instead of across the internet as a text message attachment? Because I do the latter plenty, but pretty much never AirDrop anything to anybody, even if they're sitting next to me.

TheAceOfHearts:

Long overdue, there should really be an open standard for wireless sharing of files. Windows? macOS? Linux? Android? iOS? Switch2? PS5? Doesn't matter, just open the wireless file transfer window and it should just work. Having to install third-party apps for such basic functionality is ridiculous.

If we had a functional government every major tech CEO would get called by congress, grilled about this bullshit, and told to sort it out unless they want to get some bullshit legislation shoved down their throat.

hshdhdhj4444:

Of course, AirDrop is absolutely awful.

Is the Android equivalent any better?

reactormonk:

Shoutout to https://localsend.org/ - it can even open a local webserver if needed.

somanyphotons:

Am I right to assume that they simply implemented AirDrop without discussing with Apple?

rckt:

At the same time as we have companies trying to push their humanoid robots with AI and all, we finally have devices able to communicate with each other again. Vendor locking is such a stupid thing.

averysmallbird:

What are the chances that this is made possible because of the DMA?

olly994:

Just use Wormhole for file transfer. Small and easy to use. I have put on all my computers, laptops and phones.

prmoustache:

Aren't most people just sending files over whatsapp/signal/whatever instant messaging apps they use?

bigyabai:

Duopoly who?

mcoliver:

Why only the pixel 10? What piece of hardware is the pixel 9 (one year old) missing?

OptionOfT:

The fact that I get excited about this is actually a good representation much vendor lock there is.

We used to be able to send files over Bluetooth before the iPhone came out.

leshenka:

What would it take to make it work when reception is set to "contacts"?

moi2388:

Eww, green files?

/s

netsharc:

Ah, makes me think of MacOS system 7 days. MacOS formatted the 3.5" disks with its own filesystem, so if you copied a file onto it, and put the disk in a Windows PC (or DOS?), the PC would go "Huh?".

3 decades later, hooray, now we can share files between Android and iPhone!

item.title: Launch HN: Poly (YC S22) – Cursor for Files
item.description:
Hello world, this is Abhay from Poly (https://poly. We also provide an integrated agent that can take actions on your files such as creating, editing, summarizing, and researching. We also have rate limits for agent use that vary at different tiers.

HN Discussion

Read Original Article

Top 5 Comments:

saadatq:

When I read “Cursor for Files” my mind went to “app for reading and diffing content (i.e markdown) which I was very excited about.

Fraaaank:

I'd rather see a demo instead of a highly edited video with split second shots of the product.

bangaladore:

Nitpick: Cursor for Files makes approximately zero sense to me given what I see here.

Feedback:

Supporting an enterprise air gapped solution of this clearly has huge value. It really doesn't matter where the data is stored if the indexing / embedding is happening on your infrastructure.

Enterprises with compliance requirements are quite likely the types of clients looking for ways to save time searching through petabytes of data.

prasoonds:

This is really cool! I suck at organizing my filesystem and I've lost track of how many times I had to find _that ONE_ PDF which I KNOW I have but cannot find! This would have solved that many times over.

However, at least for my use-case, this is a very infrequent problem. So, a monthly subscription and the security risk wouldn't be worth it. Though I'm certain there are people who work with files all day and for them, this might be god-send!

akersten:

Hooking up the Internet to my filesystem is scary. What security measures are in place to ensure a compromise of your infrastructure doesn't compromise mine?

item.title: The Lions Operating System
item.description:
Components are joined together using the Microkit tool. As far as is practical, operating systems components do a single thing. To be successful, many more components are needed.

HN Discussion

Read Original Article

item.title: Show HN: F32 – An Extremely Small ESP32 Board
item.description:
Clean the board again with 99% alcohol and verify all the pads on this side have some solder on them. Repeat with Bottom side. Clean entire board using alcohol and a fine toothbrush.

HN Discussion

Read Original Article

Top 3 Comments:

NuclearPM:

> This can be seen in my highly necessary depiction below.

I love this. Fun and insightful article. Thank you.

anyg:

If it is a little bigger to incorporate a bigger chip antenna and some GPIO pins, it is going to be very useful for a lot of IoT projects!!

tmpfs:

This is a very cool experiment, even if the board doesn't end up being that practical (the antenna hack is going to be an ongoing issue I think) your documentation looks great at a glance!

item.title: The Firefly and the Pulsar
item.description:
If that seems an odd choice, consider that this is a non-human entity that uses its own methods to communicate with its fellow creatures. If fireflies can communicate against their local background using optical flashes, how would that communication be altered with an astrophysical background, and what can this tell us about structure and detectability. In the realm of optical SETI, for example, how much would an optical signal have to contrast with the background stars in its direction so that it becomes distinguishable as artificial.

HN Discussion

Read Original Article

item.title: Show HN: Tangent – Security log pipeline powered by WASM
item.description:
Tangent Stream processing without DSLs. Tangent ships with everything you need to develop, test, and benchmark your own transforms: tangent plugin scaffold – generate plugin boilerplate tangent plugin compile – compile plugins to WASM tangent plugin test – run plugin tests tangent bench – measure throughput and latency before deploying tangent run – start the Tangent runtime Why use Tangent. Installation Quickstart Runtime Deepdive WASM Plugins Authoring Community CLI Overview tangent run tangent plugin scaffold tangent plugin compile tangent plugin test tangent bench Configuration tangent.

HN Discussion

Read Original Article
